video_title: GregtheGreek (Sprinter) - Building Economic Trust for Solvers
description: This talk explores trust economics solvers and users in blockchain systems, addressing opacity, centralization risks, and profit margins. Solutions include standardized interfaces, reputation systems, and mechanisms that return value to users

transcript.aggregated_text: and okay, I think we're good. Uh my name is Greg. I'm from Sprinter and also one of the co-founders at Chain Safe. And today I'm going to be talking about uh uh markets specifically pertaining to solvers and the solver market where it sits today. Um and a little bit of an in-depth analysis on kind of like where it can go to be economically viable. And so just a quick, you know, recap on what solvers are. Basically, they're just it's just off-chain code, whether it's an agent or just code itself that's effectively trying to find an optimal solution given a user outcome. A user outcome can be I want a token. Could be I want to go somewhere. Could be I want to enter a certain position on a specific chain. you figure out based the the solver figures out based on the user's point of view, their world view of what they have, where they are to basically get them to that spot in a simplified manner. There's two popularized solvers today. There's a third one that I won't be discussing. And so the two ones are AMM solvers. If anyone here has used cow swap, um then that's like basically that's run by about 21 solvers. And then there's crosschain solvers found in like a cross which is the most popular one, Dbridge, Synapse and a few others. And so those ones have slightly different variations, right? They all do the same thing which the first problem the first thing they need to do is ensure they have adequate liquidity or find liquidity. Um in the cow swap case, a lot of them use onchain liquidity to source that. And the main difference you see is that there's route optimization on the AMM side where versus on the crosschain side it's simply do you have the liquidity on the other side on the other chain where the user wants to go just give it to them. The crosschain solvers are a little bit dumber. They're just like a very simple relay. Um whereas the AMM ones it's a game of whack-a-ole. You're effectively constantly optimizing your algorithm to just like get that extra one cent spread out. Um, and so the competition between the two is a little bit different. Uh, which we'll get into a little bit, but this is just some primer. Make sure we're all there. Um, and quickly, solvers aren't very new. Cowsoft introduced them in 2021. They were popular, they were first talked about by the Anoma team. Um, Chris goes kind of like standardized the concept of intense and that a solver, an offchain agent would have to execute on that to make it work. And in 2022 till 2024, it's solvers are everywhere. Unis swaps launched them. You know, we've got things like across. We have things like one inch fusion. You know, they're basically dominating. And at this point, about 30 to 40% of total DEX volume alone is being routed through some sort of solver. Um most people aren't the trend is going to that way because you get better price discovery and the trend is just continuing. It's growth month over month. um and even cross-chain protocols, we're starting to see a big dominance happen there. Um obviously the message passing bridge is you know still peak but it's starting to take over and that's just simply because you can get the best price by hopping through a series of tokens through different liquidity sources rather than just going to unis swap. You know, a really good example is you want to go from USDC to some shitcoin and there's a really good chance that like USDC to ETH on unis swap will give you a better price pair than you can go to balancer and then eventually go back to unis swap and then get your, you know, fartcoin and that's the best path, but as a user you'd never do that and you could actually extract an extra couple percentage points that way. That's why it's taking off is because they're optimizing dramatically. Um, you know, running a solver isn't the cheapest operation and it's it looks cheap when you see this. It doesn't look too bad per month like right like 100 somethingk. That's like the most bare bones minimal setup. That's not playing whack-a-ole. That's not really doing R&D. This isn't accounting for penalties. And this also doesn't account for the fact that this is a game of BPS, which means it's a game of volume. If you're only making one BPS on a trade, you need to be doing a serious amount of volume to be considered, you know, profitable. Um, and so it's a very tough game. Most of these teams scale up to four or six people, this is like basically like one or two engineering uh staffing members. Um, and so as you start to add more sources to get more order flow, this becomes a very expensive game. Um, and it's very very competitive. And lightly talk on this. So if we see in the second column here volume and revenue I think this is the most important one we see that cow swap distributes about like what 25% roughly a quarter of their actually less h about a quarter of their total revenue to solvers that's about 570 ETH um gets distributed back to the solvers who are doing the work the rest of it sits there um this was last year uh January till today till April um where in a cross you can see that they don't take a fee and that just goes direct to solver. In both in the across case, the average fee is like two three basis points unless you go private liquidity. Um, private order flow, sorry, where you might have a deal where that you can get it higher. Otherwise, you're dealing with about razor thin margins like 1 to 3 BPS. Um, and what's important to talk about is their auction models. Cow swap has a relatively complicated auction model. It uses a mix of second price batched and off-chain sealed bids. What that really means is that you feed in a quote from the ser from the cowop server basically saying hey this sorry a user feeds in basically a trade that they want. Um and that trade basically uh comes back to the solvers and the solvers give a quote they get they try to cow swab tries to batch them as well as the solvers try to batch them to net them and then that gets uh the best bid you know gets uh revealed at the end. Um, it's a bit complicated, but it gets a pretty good price. Um, and there's some problems that we'll talk about in a bit. And the difference is here 21 solvers in cow swap and 78. You've got like one or two engineers. You're just trying to do this. This is what it costed to go break even. Um there's three people in the survivor zone. There's one person and it's that tallest one that's well above the survival zone. So, they are making profit probably about like two to three ETH per day. Everybody else is underneath the trapezoid for the last year and a half. Everybody has been underneath the green shaded area. Everybody is dying. Um there's multiple reasons. A lot of people will run this code run that will compete on cow swap purely for the algorithmic reasons so that they can sell services elsewhere. So they take it as kind of like an engineering R&D loss. But generally speaking, the auction model like the way it works today does not work extremely well. Um, and we're talking like what 10 20k a month like like it nobody's making money. The main reason is the x-axis here is what we call the ideal reward. So this is what you would receive should you have actually like won the auction and there were no errors, reverts or penalties applied during the process because there's that can happen in many different ways. Um, and then the the y-axis is your capture ratio. So this is like how much of it how many of those auctions you're actually winning. You can see at the top right here, there's a big bulk of people that win a ton of auctions, right? So, they cap they they basically capture a ton, but they get hit with so many penalties that they can barely get to that 50 E ideal reward. Um, so this is a bit of a problem obviously. Uh, the main reason for it, I don't Yeah, I don't have it on that slide. The main reason for this is due to liquidity. It's a fundamental problem of liquidity. If you can price your liquidity slightly cheaper, and a lot of this comes from the sex arbitrage or simply larger market makers being able to have access to funds, you're able to price your liquidity a penny less than everybody else in the market because you know what all the going rates are. So if we look at across um we have a very kind of similar setup going up here. Um you can see there's like one dominant player. That dominant player kind of takes everything. Um and when you know this talks about markets more than the liquidity side and so if we talk about markets the question comes what can we learn from tradfi truly like trady does a lot of things really well does a lot of things really poorly but what's really done really well is the market maker side because it's super efficient if we remove the you know illegal stuff that tends to happen um we have zero checks on antitrust, contestability.
